unnatural", one says, then the other says, "Yes it is, and it's provable"; 
then comes the "Black Widow" type of arguments.

Whether something is natural or not has absolutely no bearing on whether or 
not something is moral or not.  It goes without saying that many things 
exist in nature that are not moral. That's a red herring I won't chase.

If the argument is, "Homosexuality is unnatural", then that argument is 
completely false because homosexuality is natural: It exists in nature, it 
has a strong genetic basis, and there are many other reasons I can bring up 
to show the same.

Whether or not is is "moral" and how it fits into Darwin's Theory of 
Evolution are other topics of discussion.

Whereas the Bible, the Word of God, has made a unique contribution

therefore, be it


Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United

authorized and requested to designate 1983 as a national "Year of

the Bible" in recognition of both the formative influence the Bible

has been for our Nation, and our national need to study and apply

the teachings of the Holy Scriptures.

Approved October 4, 1982.

Kindly read Article XIV, Section 1 of the Constitution. It explains that 
American citizens cannot vote on the rights of other American citizens 
(i.e. Proposition 8 in CA in 2008 was unconstitutional). It also explains 
that the will of the majority does not and can not eliminate rights for the 
minority.

Case in point, the Brown v. Board Of Education verdict illustrates exactly 
why the rights of people should never be put up for a vote. After the 
SCOTUS handed down the decision, the general U.S. population was not 
immediately welcoming towards it. 

Virginia Senator Harry F. Byrd, Sr. organized the Massive Resistance 
movement that included the closing of schools rather than desegregating 
them.

Texas Attorney General John Ben Shepperd organized a campaign to generate 
legal obstacles for implementation of desegregation.

Arkansas Governor Orval Faubus called out his state's National Guard to 
block black students' entry to Little Rock Central High School.

In Mississippi fear of violence prevented any plaintiff from bringing a 
school desegregation suit for nine years after Brown v .Board Of Education. 
When Medgar Evers sued to desegregate Jackson, Mississippi schools in 1963, 
White Citizens Council member Byron De La Beckwith murdered him. He was not 
convicted of said murder until 1994. 

Alabama Gov. George Wallace personally blocked the door to Foster 
Auditorium at the University of Alabama to prevent the enrollment of two 
black students. *SIDENOTE*: Kim Davis is really this generation's George 
Wallace, regardless of whether she wants to admit it or not.

Other cities in the south, like Greensboro, NC abided by the SOCTUS ruling 
in public, but covertly attempted to create legal obstacles to 
desegregation. 

Had desegregation in schools been left up to the voting process via the 
people, it would have most likely been voted down. This is why that clause 
in the Constitution is so important, and why it was curicial for the SCOTUS 
to hand down the decision regarding that matter. The same principle applies 
to gay marriage.

So no, it's not all about the U.S. voting system. At least not on this 
issue.

A tiiiiiny bit off topic, but I think it's good to clarify...

Pedophilia (as with many sexual 'dysfunctions') tends to develop in early 
childhood. Some may claim that they were born with these things when in 
actuality it stems from quirks in your early developmental stages. With 
sexual orientation (ie. Straight/gay/etc) these things are developed as we 
develop into physical human beings. Sexuality is part of a biological 
process-- people are born heterosexual as a means to fuel procreation (in 
it's simplest, biological sense). Homosexuality has been linked to a 
potential excess testosterone/estrogen in opposite genders, however very 
few studies have been done in this sense and therefore I don't state this 
as fact-- only speculation.  Perhaps this is wrong, and homosexuality or 
other forms of sexuality stem from childhood experience. However, through 
counselling, therapy, and conditioning, homosexuality has yet to be truly 
cured. Therefore it can be assumed that homosexuality is not something as 
frivolous as learned or encouraged behaviour, and is instead very deeply 
rooted in someone's person. 

It's also important to note that pedophiles do not seek love or affection 
from children, and are only sexually driven (from what we know-- nobody 
studies these things because they are taboo). Homosexuals, on the other 
hand, are interested in long-term, loving and committed relationships with 
each other (or CAN be). Perhaps not all-- but that is also true for 
heterosexuals as well. The difference here is sexual interest vs. sexual 
orientation. They aren't exactly comparable because the intent of each 
party is drastically different. 

Pedophilia is an issue that plagues many people. There are people who have 
these tendencies and loathe themselves because they can't stop it (because 
many therapists and counsellors refuse to treat them). As with homosexuals, 
they should not be condemned and socially outcast. Pedophiles need help, 
because their sexual dysfunction could potentially be curable. It has been 
proven time and time again through clinical trials that homosexuality is 
not curable. "Neurohormonal Functioning and Sexual Orientation: A Theory of 
Homosexuality-Heterosexuality" by Lee Elis and M. Ashley Arnes is an 
excellent report on this and has many reputable references to check out on 
the topic!

Ultimately, consent is a key form in this. Any form of sexual act should be 
acceptable as long as it involves people who can consent. Who can make the 
decision to say 'yes. I want to do this.', and as long as this act does not 
harm anyone who is non-consenting. For example, young children from 
newborns to around thirteen years of age cannot consent (though some may 
argue for older ages, but this is a social construct and is up for debate). 
Animals cannot consent, either, which is why bestiality is taboo as well. 
Incest is taboo because of the birth defects that can affect children born 
of these acts. Homosexuality does not envelop any of these things, where 
pedophilia arguably can.

Just to clear things up with everyone, I want to say that I have no qualms 
with people who are pedophiles, yet don't act on their fantasies/desires, 
and there are plenty who fit that description.  What I referred to as a 
pedophile was a person who acts on their sexual attraction to children, 
but, upon looking up the definition for "pedophile," I came to realize that 
a more appropriate term would have been "child molester."  I think that 
there is a lot of misinformation out there on the term "pedophile," and 
many people, myself included, have been mislead into thinking the term is 
synonymous with "child molester."  I've now become enlightened otherwise, 
and hope this clears up any confusion among those who thought that I was 
suggesting that an adult who feels sexual attraction towards a child always 
acts on those feelings.  I never intended to suggest that.  I was merely 
using the incorrect term, as it turns out.  I will say, however, that I 
don't feel that this invalidates my argument in any way, and I'll explain 
why.  Bizzle was comparing the base desire of homosexuals and pedophiles, 
and suggesting that people should therefore discriminate against 
homosexuals just as they do pedophiles.  The problem with this argument is 
that it's wrong to discriminate against either group for their feelings 
alone.  It is, however, correct to take a stand against pedophiles who act 
non-consensually (in other words, child molesters), yet incorrect to take a 
stand against homosexuals who act consensually.  The reasons being that a 
child molester who engages in non-consensual actions towards a child is 
harming that child, yet a homosexual who engages in consensual actions 
towards another is not harming anyone.  As such, as I've previously stated 
several times, Bizzle's argument doesn't really hold weight.
